journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Anatomic Characteristics and Radiographic References of the Anterolateral and Posteromedial Bundles of the Posterior Cruciate Ligament

article-meta.aff: †Department of Trauma Surgery and Sports Traumatology, Academic Hospital Feldkirch, Feldkirch, Austria
‡Division of Clinical and Functional Anatomy, Department of Anatomy, Histology and Embryology, Medical University Innsbruck, Innsbruck, Austria
Investigation performed at Medical University Innsbruck, Innsbruck, Austria

author-notes.corresp: *Michael Osti, Department of Trauma Surgery and Sports Traumatology, Academic Hospital Feldkirch, Carinagasse 47, 6800 Feldkirch, Austria (e-mail: michael.osti@lkhf.at).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Anatomic graft tunnel placement is reported to be essential in double-bundle posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) reconstruction. A measurement system that correlates anatomy and radiographs is lacking so far.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To define the femoral and tibial attachments of the anterolateral (AL) and posteromedial (PM) bundles and to correlate them with digital and radiographic images to establish a radiographic anatomy based on anatomic landmarks and evaluate whether radiographs can serve as an accurate method for intraoperative and postoperative assessments of tunnel placement.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Descriptive laboratory study.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Fifteen human cadaveric knee specimens were used. After preparation, the insertion areas of the 2 fiber bundles were marked with colorants, and high-definition digital images were obtained. With radiopaque tubes placed in the center of each bundle’s footprint, anteroposterior and lateral radiographs were created. A measurement grid system was superimposed to determine the position of the AL and PM bundles’ femoral and tibial insertion areas on both digital images and radiographs. The measurement zones were numbered 1 to 16, starting in the anterosuperior corner and ending in the posteroinferior corner.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: On radiographs and digital images, the femoral centers of the AL and PM bundles were found in zones 2 and 7, respectively. The tibial centers of the AL and PM bundles were found at 47.88% and 50.93%, respectively, of the total mediolateral diameter, 83.09% and 92.29%, respectively, of the total anteroposterior diameter, and 3.53 mm and 8.57 mm, respectively, inferior from the tibial plateau on radiographs.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: This study provides a geometric characterization of the AL and PM bundles of the PCL and establishes a reliable and feasible correlation system between anatomy and radiography based on anatomic landmarks.

sec.title: Clinical Relevance:
sec.p: Accurate definition of the insertion sites of the PCL is essential for anatomic double-bundle reconstruction. The results of our study may be used as a reference for intraoperative and postoperative assessments of correct femoral and tibial tunnel placements.

body.p: Numerous reconstructive procedures addressing acute and chronic injuries of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) have been developed to restore knee joint stability. The necessity to consider both the anterolateral (AL) and the posteromedial (PM) bundle when aiming at an anatomic reproduction of normal PCL function has been established by several clinical and biomechanical studies.7,12,14,18,20 Double-bundle techniques require accurate information about anatomic position and area of attachment§ as well as reliable and feasible methods for intraoperative and postoperative verifications of correct graft tunnel placement.9,13 Only a few reports evaluate the radiographic anatomy of both fiber bundles of the PCL.13 Comparative data from anatomic and radiological correlations are lacking so far. Precise descriptive anatomy of the femoral and tibial footprints of the AL and PM bundles and a reproducible reference system to radiographic images might improve the ability to reconstruct both bundles of the PCL effectively.4,6,9,13,19 The objective of this study was (1) to obtain geometric anatomic data that characterize the dimension of the AL and PM bundles and their footprints, (2) to digitally determine the position of the centers of the AL and PM bundles’ femoral and tibial insertion areas within a reference system based on anatomic landmarks, and (3) to correlate these results with radiographic images to establish a radiographic anatomy that serves as a reliable instrument for intraoperative and postoperative assessments of anatomic graft tunnel placement.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: A total of 15 cadaveric knee specimens from 7 female and 8 male donors with no evidence of surgical scars and no instability on clinical examination were used for this study. Because joint mobility is usually limited in cadaveric specimens and clinical tests have inferior significance, the integrity of all ligamentous structures was verified during dissection. The age of the donors at the time of death averaged 82.1 ± 8.3 years (mean ± standard deviation). Seven right and 8 left knees with at least 30 cm of bone and soft tissue proximal and distal to the joint line were investigated. To determine a consistent variable for comparison of the sample, the mediolateral and anteroposterior diameters of the tibial plateau and the width, depth, and height of the intercondylar notch were used.

After gross dissection of skin, soft tissue, and muscles, the posterior capsule of the knee joint was identified and removed. The PCL and the posterior meniscofemoral ligament (Wrisberg) and its tibial and femoral attachments were exposed. For a precise dissection of the AL and PM fiber bundles and their insertion areas, a surgical microscope (magnification factor 10) (Type S5, Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany) and microsurgical instruments were utilized. To accomplish an accurate preparation of the femoral attachments of the PCL, the lateral femoral condyle was removed with an oscillating saw. The centers of the insertion areas of the AL and PM bundles were marked with cannulas. To describe the anatomic characteristics of the 2 bundles, a 3-dimensional measurement of the femoral and tibial insertion areas was performed, and the bundles’ length and diameter were recorded using a digital slide gauge (EMC, Warsaw, Poland). The metering precision of the instrument is specified with 0.01 mm. Afterward, the AL and PM bundles were individually removed from their femoral and tibial attachment sites, and the insertion areas were marked with different colorants. High-resolution digital images with defined settings were obtained using a tripod-mounted digital camera (D70, Nikon Corp, Tokyo, Japan) at a distance of 60 cm. For accurate measurements, all images were calibrated by including a measuring tape parallel to the image plane. Medial femoral views and posteroanterior and proximal-distal (axial) tibial views of each specimen were collected and transferred onto a computer for a digital calculation of the femoral and tibial footprints. For reference analysis of the position of the femoral insertion area of the AL and PM bundles, 2 measurement grid systems consisting of 16 rectangular zones (based on the description for radiographic referencing of the anterior cruciate ligament by Bernard et al3) were superimposed on the images with lateral femoral views. The measurement zones were numbered 1 to 16, starting in the anterosuperior corner and ending in the posteroinferior corner (Figure 1). One measurement grid (M1) was inscribed into the medial femoral condyle and was defined by the cartilage outlines and the intercondylar roof. The second measurement grid (M2) was defined by the intercondylar roof (Blumensaat line), a tangent through the medial femoral condyle, and 2 perpendicular lines through the intersection between the intercondylar roof and anterior and posterior edges of the medial femoral condyle. Our intention was to utilize femoral measurement grid systems that are suitable for both arthroscopic views (M1) and radiographs (M2). Cartilage borders and the intercondylar roof can be identified during arthroscopy, and a circumscription of the medial femoral condyle is practical for radiographic images. The position of the femoral insertion areas of the AL and PM bundles was determined as a proportion of the intercondylar depth, d, and the intercondylar height, h (Figure 1). The position of the tibial insertion areas of the AL and PM bundles was determined as a proportion of the total mediolateral diameter of the tibial plateau (measured according to the description by Amis and Jakob2) on posteroanterior views and as a proportion of the total anteroposterior diameter of the tibial plateau on axial views. The superior-inferior distance between the insertion area of the AL and PM bundles and the connecting line between the medial and lateral tibial plateaus were measured in posteroanterior views (Figure 2). After correlation of anatomy and digital images, the centers of the femoral and tibial insertion areas of the AL and PM bundles were marked with radiopaque tubes (4 mm in length and 2 mm in diameter, pressed directly into the bone at the center of the bundle’s footprint, which was defined as the approximate half of both diameters of the insertion area), and standardized lateral and anteroposterior radiographic views with defined settings were obtained (tube voltage, 60 kV; dosage, 3.2 mAs; film focus distance, 100 cm) (DX-D500, AGFA Corp, Mortsel, Belgium). Radiographic analysis of the position of the femoral and tibial insertion areas of the AL and PM bundles was then conducted by superimposing the same measurement grid systems as described for digital images (Figure 3). All results refer to the center of the footprint of the ligament insertion.

caption.p: Lateral view of a right knee of an anatomic specimen: measurement grids on the medial intercondylar wall (black, M1; white, M2). Anterolateral (AL) bundle (green) in zone 2 and posteromedial (PM) bundle (red) in zone 7 relative to M2. Intercondylar depth (d) and height (h) of the PM bundle for the reference relative to M2. Corresponding parameters for the AL bundle relative to M1 (black arrows).

Axial view of a left knee of an anatomic specimen, demonstrating the measurement of the anteroposterior diameter of the tibial plateau and the distance of the anterolateral (red, AL 2) and posteromedial (green) bundles from the anterior tibial edge.

Radiograph of a right knee, lateral (A) and anteroposterior (B) views: radiographic measurement grid enclosing the medial femoral condyle demonstrates the position of the anterolateral (AL) bundle insertion in zone 2 and the posteromedial (PM) bundle insertion in zone 7 (radiopaque tubes). Intercondylar depth (dPM) and height (hPM) for the PM bundle and distance from the anterior tibial edge (PM 2) (A). Tibial AL and PM bundle insertions demonstrate the distance from the medial edge of the tibial plateau (PM 1) and from the connecting line between the medial and lateral tibial surfaces (PM 3) (B).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Continuous variables were compared between digital images and radiographs using the t test. Statistical significance was defined as P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: On specimens, the mediolateral and anteroposterior diameters of the tibial plateau averaged 79.26 ± 5.37 mm and 54.40 ± 3.69 mm, respectively. The width (mediolateral diameter), depth (anteroposterior diameter), and height (superoinferior diameter) of the intercondylar notch averaged 18.28 ± 3.67 mm, 16.89 ± 3.36 mm, and 14.18 ± 3.17 mm, respectively.

The overall length and diameter of the PCL averaged 36.08 ± 2.32 mm and 11.03 ± 1.72 mm, respectively. The individual results for length, diameter, and dimension of the insertion areas of the AL and PM bundles are demonstrated in Table 1. The digitally calculated cross-sectional area of the femoral and tibial footprints of the AL bundle averaged 0.53 ± 0.09 cm2 on the femur and 0.62 ± 0.10 cm2 on the tibia. The average cross-sectional area of the PM bundle was 0.55 ± 0.08 cm2 at the femoral insertion and 0.54 ± 0.13 cm2 at the tibial insertion.

caption.p: Anatomic Characteristics of the Anterolateral and Posteromedial Bundles of the Posterior Cruciate Ligamenta

fn.label: a
fn.p: AL, anterolateral; PM, posteromedial; PCL, posterior cruciate ligament.

sec.title: Femoral Measurements
sec.p: On the femur, the lateral lengths of the rectangular measurement grid (M1), inscribed into the wall of the medial femoral condyle, averaged 28.8 ± 3.74 mm for the intercondylar depth (d) and 17.24 ± 1.87 mm for the intercondylar height (h) on digital images. For M2, we found the corresponding values to be 47.40 ± 3.90 mm and 27.49 ± 2.69 mm, respectively. On radiographs, the corresponding values averaged 32.80 ± 5.23 mm for edge d and 16.97 ± 28.1 mm for edge h, respectively. The relative values for AL depth, AL height, PM depth, and PM height, expressed as a percentage of the intercondylar depth (d) and intercondylar height (h) were 25.81%, 19.91%, 52.82%, and 54.61%, respectively, on digital images for M1 and 42.14%, 13.87%, 61.14%, and 36.89%, respectively, on digital images for M2. The corresponding values on radiographic images were 42.21%, 13.21%, 63.27%, and 37.77%, respectively (Table 2). Based on the 16 rectangular measurement zones, the AL bundle footprint cumulated in the corner between zones 1, 2, 5, and 6 of M1 and in zone 2 of M2 on digital images and in zone 2 on radiographs. The PM bundle footprint focused in the corner between zones 6, 7, 10, and 11 of M1 and in zone 7 of M2 on digital images and in zone 7 on radiographs.

caption.p: Absolute and Relative Values for the Position of the Femoral Center of the Anterolateral and Posteromedial Bundles on Digital Images and Radiographsa

tr.td: AL and PM bundles on digital images (measurement grid M1)
AL and PM bundles on digital images (measurement grid M2)
AL and PM bundles on radiographs

sec.title: Tibial Measurements
sec.p: On the tibia, the total anteroposterior and the mediolateral diameter of the tibial plateau averaged 47.62 ± 4.12 mm and 79.66 ± 5.47 mm, respectively, on digital images. The mediolateral and anteroposterior positions of the footprints were referenced to the mediolateral and anteroposterior diameters of the tibial plateau. The footprints of the AL and PM bundles were located on average 39.30 ± 4.30 mm and 41.15 ± 4.69 mm, respectively, lateral from the medial edge of the tibial plateau in posteroanterior views (AL 1 and PM 1), on average 40.52 ± 3.42 mm and 44.06 ± 3.78 mm, respectively, posterior from the anterior edge of the tibial plateau in axial views (AL 2 and PM 2), and on average 5.32 ± 2.93 mm and 12.86 ± 3.95 mm, respectively, inferior from the connecting line between the medial and lateral tibial joint surfaces in posteroanterior views (AL 3 and PM 3).

The total anteroposterior and mediolateral diameters of the tibial plateau averaged 57.43 ± 3.69 mm and 81.20 ± 5.95 mm, respectively, on radiographs. The footprints of the AL and PM bundles were located on average 38.93 ± 5.00 mm and 41.47 ± 6.21 mm, respectively, lateral from the medial edge of the tibial plateau (AL 1 and PM 1), on average 47.41 ± 3.36 mm and 63.00 ± 3.64 mm, respectively, posterior from the anterior edge of the tibial plateau on lateral views (AL 2 and PM 2), and on average 3.53 ± 2.00 mm and 8.27 ± 2.34 mm, respectively, inferior from the connecting line between the lateral and medial joint surfaces on anteroposterior views (AL 3 and PM 3). The relative values for the position of the tibial footprint of the AL bundle on digital images were 49.27% lateral from the medial border of the tibial plateau with respect to the total mediolateral diameter and 85.15% posterior from the anterior edge of the tibial plateau with respect to the total anteroposterior diameter. The corresponding values for the PM bundle were 51.57% and 92.54%, respectively. On radiographic images, these values were found to be 47.88% and 83.09%, respectively, for the AL bundle and 50.93% and 92.29%, respectively, for the PM bundle (Table 3).

caption.p: Absolute and Relative Values for the Position of the Tibial Center of the Anterolateral and Posteromedial Bundles on Digital Images and Radiographsa

tr.td: AL and PM bundles on digital images
AL and PM bundles on radiographs

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of our study (1) give comprehensive information about the anatomic characteristics of the AL and PM bundles and the corresponding insertion areas, (2) provide a reliable femoral measurement grid system for both intra-articular view and radiographic images, (3) generate the 3-dimensional geometry of the AL and PM bundles’ tibial footprints in both the anatomic specimen and radiographic image, and (4) establish a reproducible correlation between anatomy and radiography. To our knowledge, this is the first report that isolates both femoral and tibial footprints into AL and PM fiber bundles and references these findings to anatomic landmarks in radiographic images.

Regarding the PCL and individual AL and PM bundle length and diameter, our data serve as a basis for anatomic characterization. Because studies about the insertion geometry of the anterior cruciate ligament are much more voluminous, our investigation contributes valuable information to existing knowledge about the PCL.22

The cross-sectional areas of the AL and PM bundles’ femoral and tibial insertions are similar to the observations of Takahashi et al24 except for the PM bundle’s tibial insertion, which was half the size in our study compared with the result reported by Takahashi et al. In a quantitative analysis of the AL and PM bundles’ insertion areas, Harner et al11 found slightly higher values than we did.

Comparing our anatomic results of the measurement grid system M1, which ends at the cartilage borders and offers orientation for arthroscopic intraoperative views, with the results published by Edwards et al,7 we find a rather similar position for both bundles in the corner between zones 1, 2, 5, and 6 for the AL bundle and in the corner between zones 6, 7, 10, and 11 for the PM bundle. Extending the margins of this system to the articular cartilage surface, which is suitable for plain radiography and computed tomography,9 results in the measurement grid M2, which has not yet been used to determine the PCL femoral attachments in anatomic specimens. The data measured from M2 on digital images in our study highly correlate with the results obtained from the radiographic images.

In a recent study, Lorenz et al,13 although using an alternative origin for their measurements at the posteroinferior corner of a comparable measurement grid, found the femoral insertion of the AL and PM bundles at 62% and 51%, respectively, of the total intercondylar depth. The relative intercondylar heights of the 2 bundles were located at 16% and 35%, respectively. Whereas the values for the relative intercondylar height seem comparable, our results for the intercondylar depth tended to be smaller, locating the insertion areas deeper into the intercondylar wall. Our rationale for setting the knee in a supine position for femoral measurement was the conceivable easier orientation when applying the method during surgery. We believe that removal of the lateral femoral condyle and detachment of the fiber bundles from their original insertion area prior to labeling with a colorant or radiopaque material in combination with a microsurgical dissection technique might be the most important key to a superior exposure and definite visualization of the region of interest. The similarity of our anatomic and radiographic data that arose from obtaining digital images for a computer-assisted determination of both landmarks and distances in a first step and comparing the results to measurements in radiographic images in a second step might prove the accuracy of our approach. We were not able to detect any statistically significant differences between specimen and radiographic measurements for the measurement system M2. The AL bundle’s femoral insertion cumulated in zone 2 and the PL bundle’s attachment cumulated in zone 7 both on digital images and on radiographs. We agree with Lorenz et al13 concerning the tibial insertion in anteroposterior and lateral views (51% of the mediolateral diameter of the tibial plateau with respect to the lateral border and 13% inferiorly to the medial tibial plateau with respect to the sagittal diameter of the tibial plateau), even though we measured the superior-inferior distance between insertion site and tibial plateau in an anteroposterior and not in a lateral projection and also distinguished AL and PM bundle footprints on the tibia. However, we consider the issue debatable, whether a radiographic division of the tibial attachments of both bundles adds consequential information to existing knowledge, the more so as tibial double-bundle techniques are rather infrequently performed.5

Using computed tomography to evaluate the PCL attachments, Greiner et al9 reported a distance to the anterior articular cartilage surface of 18.7 mm and a distance to the Blumensaat line of 8.9 mm. In our study, digital images and radiographs revealed the corresponding values to be approximately 20.5 mm and 3.5 mm, respectively, for the AL bundle and 30 mm and 9.5 mm, respectively, for the PM bundle, which is close to the results for the intercondylar height published by Takahashi et al24 in an anatomic study. Accordance was found regarding the tibial insertion area, which was located at 49% of the total mediolateral diameter of the tibia by Greiner et al9 and at 48% for the AL bundle and at 51% for the PM bundle in the current study. This also confirms the findings of Edwards et al,7 who found the corresponding value to be 48%, and of Takahashi et al,24 who found it to be 51% and 50%, respectively. The anteroposterior position of the PCL was specified with 87% by Greiner et al9 and was found at 83% for the AL bundle and at 92% for the PM bundle in our investigation. Greiner et al9 noted the vertical distance from the tibial plateau to be 1.6 mm, Takahashi et al24 found 0 mm for the AL bundle and 4.6 mm for the PM bundle, and Tajima et al23 reported 1.5 mm and 6.0 mm, respectively, while our results were 5.3 mm and 12.8 mm, respectively, on digital images and 3.5 mm and 8.3 mm, respectively, on radiographs, which is close to the results of Racanelli and Drez,19 who found it to be 8 mm.

The average age of the knee specimens utilized in this study is rather high, which might be a limit to the significance of our findings. Nevertheless, the results of our investigation might be a useful support in PCL reconstruction surgery when aiming at the creation of anatomic graft tunnels and represent a further step in establishing a reliable instrument for intraoperative and postoperative assessments of correct tunnel placement by skeletal imaging.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
